page.title: 05ECOLOGY CORNISH HEDGES
page.content: The Cornish hedge marks the boundaries for fields and roads and is made of stone and earth.It is also a distinguishing feature of the landscape.The biggest stones for the foundations are called{grounders.}The width of the base of the hedge is equal to the finished height.The smallest stones are laid in a herringbone pattern known locally as {Bill and Bens}or {Jack and Jills.}To finish off,turves or{tobs}are placed for roots to grow down between the stones to hold the hedge together.A Cornish hedger can build up to 4m a dayfor which he gets paid Â£100.The hedge is a living environment for many small animals,insects and birds.In spring the hedges are ablaze with colour.Roger Clemens(hedger)says he needs to be a modest man,his skill and art are soon clothed in nature.
